contentrichtext.text: {{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=June 2008}} {{Refimprove|date=April 2008}} }} '''Mboubène''' is a town in the lower delta of the [[Senegal River]], near the mouth of the [[Marigot de Djeuss]]. The town is located on the main highway to the [[Maka-Diama dam]] at a distance of {{convert|10|km|mi|spell=us}} from the coastal city of [[Saint-Louis, Senegal]]. On French and Dutch maps, the name of the town has been spelled variously, including "MBoulene" and "Emboulan." It was called "Biffeche-Ville" during the period of the 1960s through the 1980s when it was inhabited by resettled members of the [[Sereer|Sèrèer]] ethnic group. (The Sèrèers moved away to the nearby town of [[Savoigne]].) Today, Mboubène consists of two parts: Al Madinatoul Islamiah Mboubène Peulh inhabited by [[Fula people]],<ref>An ethnicity known in [[French language|French]] as ''Peulh'' or ''Peul'', and in [[Fula language|Fula]] as ''Fulɓe''.</ref> and Mboubène Naar primarily inhabited by [[Moors]]. There is a Koranic school and general store at the former, and a royal residence at the latter. The chief economic activities are animal husbandry and gardening. Nearby agricultural fields suffer from yearly flooding and salinity. Mboubène-Peulh is governed by an appointed Chef de Village. ==References and notes== {{Reflist}} {{coord missing|Senegal}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mboubene}} [[Category:Populated places in Senegal]] {{Senegal-geo-stub}}
